newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.

text.p: PROTEST AFTERMATH CONTINUES
A Sydney union organiser has resigned and a ninth person has been arrested in the continuing aftermath of last month's pre-budget invasion of Parliament House.

Viduar Vega of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union was pictured in a Sydney newspaper last Saturday as part of the group which forced open the doors of Parliament House during the August 19 rally.
Mr Vega has not been charged by Australian Federal Police but the CFMEU says it respects his decision to resign.
A 59 year old Nowra man has today been charged with two counts of assaulting police during a protest outside the old Parliament House on August 20.
ACTU TO BUILD UNITED FRONT
The ACTU is out to build a united front in the community against aspects of the Workplace Relations Bill and the budget.
The goal was set at a three day ACTU Council meeting which has finished in the Victorian town of Lorne.

ACTU Assistant Secretary, Bill Mansfield, says the job ahead is to unite the union movement, employers, community groups and parliamentarians to defeat parts of the industrial relations reforms and budget.
Mr Mansfield warns unemployment could nudge 9 percent by the end of the year with growth slowing and cuts to labour market programs.
He also says the meeting laid to rest controversey over the pre-budget riot in Canberra and speculation about the ACTU leadership.
RECONCILIATION CONVENTION NEXT YEAR
The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation will sponsor a convention next year on how best to advance social justice, land and citizenship issues.

The convention will discuss whether reconciliation between indigenous and white Australians should be dealt with through a national document, such as the Constitution, or a series of regional agreements.
More than a thousand people from Government, industry and community groups will be invited to the Melbourne conference, which will report back to Federal Parliament.
NSW BACKS DOWN ON HOSPITAL CUTS
Funding for inner-Sydney hospitals won't now be cut to help pay for hospitals in the city's south-west and other New South Wales growth regions.
The Health Minister, Andrew Refshauge, says the Council on the Coast of Government has found the A$34 million for this, so it won't need to come from inner-city hospitals.
The cuts were seen as politically damaging for the Carr Government.
As about a thousand people protested against cuts to the Prince of Wales Hospital, its clinical director described the backdown as a a victory for common sense.
But the chairman of the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils, Alex Sanchez says it's a despicable sell-out of the people of western Sydney.
ROAD TRAINS KNOCKED BACK IN SOUTH-EAST QUEENSLAND
Road trains up to 33 metres in length and towing three trailers behind them won't be trialled on south-east Queensland roads after a backdown by the Main Roads Department.
The B-triples have prompted safety concerns from councils, police and the community.
The department will recommend that the trucks be confined to existing road train routes west of Toowoomba.
DEMOCRATS TO FORCE DEBATES ON DENTAL SCHEME
The Democrats have decided to force debates in both houses of Parliament on the Federal Government's decision to axe the Commonwealth Dental Programme.
The Government argues the programme, which will cost A$400 million over four years, is a state matter but there are no moves afoot to ensure the states continue the programme.
Democrats' health spokeswoman, Meg Lees, says debate will force Coalition MPs to defend the decision to scrap the scheme, which may cause a change of heart.
Senator Lees says the scheme's abolition will be a return to the days of people waiting in pain, and probably ending up getting teeth pulled rather than filled.
